item.title: Conditionals
item.description:
Course description

These lectures will introduce the philosophical discussion about conditionals. For this, we need to ask what the relation is between the meaning of formal languages and the meaning of natural languages.

Online resources

Outlines and handouts will be made available on:

http://msteenhagen.github.io/teaching/2018cda/

Where and when

Monday 3-4pm. Lecture Block Room 1.

Lecture 1: Meaning and natural language

This lecture will discuss Grice’s theory of sentence meaning and communicative intentions.

(Download handout here)

Suggested reading

H.P. Grice (1957), ‘Meaning’, The Philosophical Review, Vol. 66, No. 3. (Jul., 1957), pp. 377-388.

Lecture 2: Logic and conversation

This lecture will expand on Grice’s theory of sentence meaning, by considering the role and behaviour of conventional and conversational implicature.

Suggested reading

H. P. Grice (1957), ‘Logic and Conversation’ in Peter Cole and Jerry L. Morgan (eds.) Syntax and Semantics, Vol. 3, Speech Acts, New York: Academic Press 1975 (Also in Grice’s Studies in the Ways of Words)

Lecture 3: Conditionals: truth-functional approaches

This lecture will introduce the paradoxes of conditionals, which occur when we try to transition between natural and formal languages. We will try to resolve these paradoxes by using Grice’s theory of implicature.

Suggested reading

Mark Sainsbury (2001), ‘The Project of Formalization,’ (ch. 6) in Logical Forms: An Introduction to Philosophical Logic, Oxford: Blackwell, 339-391.

Lecture 4: Conditionals: non-truthfunctional approaches

In this lecture we will look at problems with the Gricean solution to the paradoxes of conditionals, and consider alternative approaches

Suggested reading

Dorothy Edgington (2008), ‘Conditionals’, in E.N. Zalta, ed., Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter Edition) [Online].

item.title: Mind-reading
item.description:
Course description

These lectures will introduce the problem of other minds and discuss the philosophical debate about mind-reading.

Online resources

Outlines and handouts will be made available on:

http://msteenhagen.github.io/teaching/2018mre/

Where and when

Monday 1-2pm. Lecture Block Room 12.

Lecture 1: Sympathy, empathy and the problem of other minds

This lecture will introduce a history of thinking about empathy and the problem of other minds. A central argument in this discussion is the Argument from Analogy. How good is this argument?

(Download handout here)

Suggested reading

Gustav Jahoda (2005), Theodor Lipps and the shift from “sympathy” to “empathy”. J. Hist. Behav. Sci., 41: 151-163. doi:10.1002/jhbs.20080

Vernon Lee (1913), The Beautiful: An Introduction to Psychological Aesthetics. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

Norman Malcolm (1958), ‘Knowledge of Other Minds’ The Journal of Philosophy, Vol. 55, No. 23, pp. 969-978.

Lecture 2: Theory theory

This lecture will critically examine the ‘Theory Theory’. Some philosophers and psychologists believe that we (and possibly other animals) use a Theory of Mind (ToM) to represent and predict the mental states of others. The theory in question is a form of folk psychology, and some suggest we use this theory both to make sense of the mental states of others as well as of our own mental states.

Lecture 3: Simulation theory

This lecture will introduce the discussion about Simulation Theory. This view holds that our knowledge of other minds is fundamentally attained through acts of mental simulation: imaginative projects in which we pretend to take up the perspective of the other. A particular focus will be on the work of Jane Heal.

Lecture 4: Empathy

In this lecture we will discuss non-reductionist approaches to mind-reading. We will examine a reading of Hume that allows the mental states of others to be directly present to us, and consider a more recent proposal by Edith Stein, according to which empathy is an intentional mode in its own right.

item.title: Induction and Causation
item.description:
Course description

These lectures will introduce the problems of induction and the metaphysics of causation (or causality, or cause and effect).

Online resources

Outlines and handouts will be made available on:

http://msteenhagen.github.io/teaching/2018inc/

Where and when

Friday 10-11. Lecture Block Room 1.

Lecture 1: Hume and the problem of induction

In this lecture I introduce the idea of induction, and discuss David Hume’s problem of induction.

(Download handout here)

Lecture 2: Goodman’s new riddle of induction

In this lecture I discuss Nelson Goodman’s ‘new riddle’ of induction, and will contrast it with the old riddle formulated by David Hume.

Lecture 3: Hume on causation

In this lecture I introduce David Hume’s sceptical approach to causation, and show how it has led the way for regularity theories of causation. There are some problems with such theories. In particular, regularity theories seem to have little to say about the particular events that seem to be fundamental to causal interaction.

Lecture 4: Causes as INUS conditions

J.L. Mackie offers an analysis that identifies these particular events as special conditions: INUS conditions. His suggestion is that something is a cause if it is at least an INUS condition for an effect. I close by discussing three problems with Mackie’s theory.

Lecture 5: Counterfactual theories

In this lecture I introduce David Lewis’ framework for thinking about counterfactual conditionals, and show how he applies this framework to a theory of causation. Causal dependence is a relation between distinct events that is defined in terms of counterfactual dependence relations between statements about these events’ occurrence (or absence thereof).

Lecture 6: The problem of redundant causation

In this lecture I continue elaborating David Lewis’ framework for thinking about causation in terms of causal and counterfactual dependence. I discuss the asymmetry and transitivity of causation, and look at cases of overdetermination and pre-emption.

item.title: Necessity, Analyticity, A Priority
item.description:
Course description

This course will introduce several key distinctions: analytic / synthetic; a priori / a posteriori; and necessary / contingent. It will cover the syllabus materials on Analyticity, A Priority, and Necessity (the first section of Paper 3, Meaning). Feel free to contact me at ms2416@cam.ac.uk if you have any suggestions, questions, or comments about this course.

General reading

An interesting and readable introductory textbook is: Sybil Wolfram (1989), Philosophical Logic: An Introduction, Oxford: Routledge.

Online resources

Outlines and handouts will be made available on: http://msteenhagen.github.io/teaching/2017plo/

Where and when

Monday 3-4pm. Lecture Block Room 1

Lecture 1: Necessity

What is necessity? Can we distinguish different forms of necessity? This lecture discusses the notion of a necessary truth, and presents a model for such truths using possible worlds. (slides)

Suggested Reading
  • W.V.O. Quine (1956), ‘Quantifiers and propositional attitudes’ The Journal of Philosophy 53, 177-187.
  • W.V.O. Quine (1943), ‘Notes on existence and necessity’ The Journal of Philosophy 40, 113-127

Lecture 2: Analyticity and A priority

What explains the necessity of truths? This lecture continues the discussion of necessary truth, and considers whether a statement’s analyticity is an adequate explanation of necessity. This leads to a classic empiricist view that necessity, analyticity and a priority stand or fall together. (slides)

Suggested Reading
  • A. J. Ayer (1946), Language, Truth and Logic (2nd ed.), London: Gollancz, ch. 4.
  • David Papineau (2012), Philosophical Devices Oxford: Oxford University Press. (Part II, Chs 4-5)

Lecture 3: Necessary but synthetic truths

Can empirical truths be necessary? This lecture introduces Kripke’s notion of a ‘rigid designator’, and considers the possibility of necessary but a posteriori truths.

For the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, Joseph LaPorte wrote a good and detailed discussion of rigid designators. As is usual with the SEP, the entry contains clear introductions of the main ideas, followed by increasingly advanced material. I don’t expect you to be able to follow all of it (yet), but I can recommend reading at least the introduction (§1) and section (§3): https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/rigid-designators/ (slides)

Suggested Reading
  • Saul A. Kripke (1971), ‘Identity and Necessity,’ in M.K. Munitz (ed.), Identity and Individuation. New York: New York University Press. 135-164. PDF

Lecture 4: Reference and description

This lecture continues our discussion of rigid designators, and considers the possibility of a priori truths that are contingent. (slides)

Suggested Reading
  • Saul A. Kripke (1971), ‘A Priori Knowledge, Necessity, and Contingency’, in P.K. Moser, ed., A Priori Knowledge (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1987), ch. 7. (Excerpt of his Naming and Necessity)

item.title: Perception
item.description:
Course description

In these lectures I will discuss different philosophical views of the nature of perceptual experience, and analyze central objections.

Where and when

Friday 3-4pm, Lecture Room 2 (Sidgwick Site Lecture Block)

Lecture 1: Naive realism

Naive realism is the view that perceptual experience fundamentally is a presentation (to us) of familiar, mind-independent objects in our environment. It is motivated by the phenomenology of perception. Perception—the Naive Realist maintains—seems to be a presentation of those objects, and without a reason to think otherwise we can just take that appearance at face value. In this lecture I discuss Naive Realism, and look at two ways of challenging it. This will allow you to compare a Naive Realist understanding of the phenomenology of perception with the more careful description offered by G.E. Moore in his work on sense data.

Suggested further reading

G.E. Moore (1925), ‘A Defence of Common Sense’ in Contemporary British Philosophy (second series), ed. J.H. Muirhead (George Allen & Unwin, London: 1925), pp. 192-233. (There’s a PDF version here)

Download slides here

Lecture 2: The Argument from Hallucination

In this lecture I will discuss the arguments from illusion and hallucination. I will try to construct the best version of each. These arguments purport to show that the kind of experience we have when we look at a tomato does not for its existence depend on anything outside the mind. Some have taken its success to imply that the objects of perception are in fact mind-dependent. It is, however, not obvious that accepting this is the only way to respond to the argument.

Suggested further reading

Craig French and Lee Walters (2016), ‘The Invalidity of the Argument from Illusion’, American Philosophical Quarterly. https://philpapers.org/rec/FRETIO-15

Download slides here

Lecture 3: Representationalism

In this lecture I will consider an alternative diagnosis of the argument from hallucination. What both sense datum theorists and naive realists accept is the idea that perceptual experience is fundamentally presentational. However, we need not assume this. What if perceptual experience is fundamentally representational? In that case, we need not postulate mind-dependent sense data, and instead say that we can be aware of familiar, mind-independent objects regardless of whether they exist or not. But what is a perceptual representation? And can we motivate this conception of experience independent of the argument from hallucination? I will end by discussing epistemological motivations for the view.

Suggested further reading

  • Michael Tye (2002), ‘Visual Qualia and Visual Content Revisited’ (Defence of representationalism)
  • Charles Travis (2004), ‘The Silence of the Senses’ (Criticism of representationalism)
  • G.E.M. Anscombe (1965), ‘The Intentionality of Sensation: A Grammatical Feature’ (Defence of intentionalism; reprinted in Vision and Mind collection edited by Noë and Thompson)
  • M.G.F. Martin (2006), ‘On Being Alienated’ (Discussion of Common Kind Assumption, Experiential Naturalism, and Naive Realism)
  • Wilfrid Sellars (1956), Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind (http://www.ditext.com/sellars/epm.html)
  • John McDowell (1994), Mind and World
  • Susanna Siegel (2010), The Contents of Visual Experience (Defence of representationalism)
  • Graeme Forbes (2006), Attitude Problems An Essay On Linguistic Intensionality (See ch.3 for an advanced discussion of perceptual verbs)
Download slides here

Lecture 4: Disjunctivism

In this final lecture I will consider a way for the naive realist to resist each of the arguments we began with. The argument from hallucination can be defused if we accept disjunctivism about experience. The disjunctivist claims that the kind of experience we have when we look at a tomato is fundamentally different from a subjectively indistinguishable hallucination. I will look at two standard objections to disjunctivism about perception: that it conflicts with vision science, and that it cannot make sense of ‘what it is like’ to hallucinate. I will argue that both objections are ultimately misguided.

Download slides here
Suggested Reading

Here’s a (progressively expanding) list of books and articles that I recommend if you are interested in following up on the topics I discuss in the lectures:

  • J.L. Austin, Sense and Sensibilia (Argument from Illusion, Sense Data)
  • Matthew Soteriou, Disjunctivism (Naive Realism, Argument from hallucination, Disjunctivism)
  • G.E.M. Anscombe, ‘The Intentionality of Sensation: A Grammatical Feature’ (Representationalism, Sense Data, Naive Realism)

item.title: Consciousness
item.description:
Course description

In this series of advanced seminars we will discuss six key contributions to the philosophical debate about the nature of consciousness. The reading list covers the Part II syllabus materials on Consciousness for the Tripos paper in Philosophy of Mind. Besides Part II students, students on the Philosophy MPhil programme are welcome to attend.

Feel free to contact me at ms2416@cam.ac.uk if you have any suggestions, questions, or comments about this course.

Reading requirement

The first reading listed for each week is required, any further readings are optional.

Online resources

Information about this course will be made available on: http://msteenhagen.github.io/teaching/2018con/

Where and when

Thursday 11:00-12:00. Lecture Block Room 10

Session 1: Phenomenal Consciousness and Access Consciousness

Required Reading

Ned Block (1995), ‘On a Confusion About a Function of Consciousness’, Behavioral and Brain Sciences, Vol. 18, No. 2, pp. 227-47.

Suggested Reading

Daniel Dennett (1981), ‘Towards a Cognitive Theory of Consciousness’, in Brainstorms. Brighton: Harvester, pp. 149-73.

David Rosenthal (1986), ‘Two Concepts of Consciousness’, Philosophical Studies, Vol. 49, pp. 329-59.

(Download handout here)

Session 2: Phenomenal Consciousness and Iconic Memory

Required Reading

Ian Phillips (2011), ‘Perception and Iconic Memory: What Sperling Doesn’t Show’, Mind & Language, Vol. 26, pp. 381-411.

Suggested Reading

Ned Block (2007), ‘Consciousness, accessibility, and the mesh between psychology and neuroscience’, Behavioral and Brain Sciences, Vol. 30, pp. 481–99.

Barry Dainton, ‘Temporal consciousness.’ The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Fall 2010 ed. Ed. Edward N. Zalta. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consciousness-temporal/

J. T. Enns and V. Di Lollo (2000), ‘What’s new in visual masking?’ Trends in Cognitive Sciences, Vol. 4, pp. 345–52.

G. Sperling (1960), ‘The information available in brief visual presentations’, Psychological Monographs, Vol. 74, No. 11.

Michael Tye (2006), ‘Content, richness, and fineness of grain.’ In T. S. Gendler and J. Hawthorne (eds), Perceptual Experience. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Demonstration of the Sperling paradigm: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GkZNHe49GcA

(Download handout here)

Session 3: The Hard Problem of Consciousness

Required Reading

David Chalmers (1996), The Conscious Mind. Oxford: Oxford University Press. Chapter 3 (‘Can consciousness be reductively explained?’)

Suggested Reading

Thomas Nagel (1974), ‘What Is It Like to Be a Bat?’ The Philosophical Review, Vol. 83, pp. 435-50.

Kathleen Akins (1993), ‘What Is It Like to Be Boring and Myopic?’ in B. Dahlbom, ed., Dennett and His Critics. 2nd ed. Cambridge, MA: Blackwell, pp. 124-60.

Peter Adamson (2005), ‘On Knowledge of Particulars’, Proceedings of the Aristotelian Society New Series 105, pp. 257-278.

(Download handout here)

Session 4: Intentionalism 1

Required Reading

Alex Byrne (2001), ‘Intentionalism Defended’, Philosophical Review, Vol. 110, pp. 199-240.

Suggested Reading

Christopher Peacocke (1983), Sense and Content. Oxford: Clarendon Press. (Chapter 1)

Amy Kind (2010), ‘Transparency and Representationalist Theories of Consciousness’, Philosophy Compass, Vol. 5, No. 10, pp. 902-13.

(Download handout here)

Session 5: Intentionalism 2

Required Reading

Alex Byrne (2001), ‘Intentionalism Defended’, Philosophical Review, Vol. 110, pp. 199-240.

Suggested Reading

James John (2005), ‘Representationism, Phenomenism, and the Intuitive View’, Philosophical Topics 33, pp. 159–184.

Casey O’Callaghan, (2008), ‘Seeing What You Hear: Cross-Modal Illusions and Perception’, Philosophical Issues 18, pp. 316-338.

(Download handout here)

Session 6: The Objectivity of Mind

Required Reading

Mark Johnston (2007), ‘Objective Mind and the Objectivity of Our Minds’ Philosophy and Phenomenological Research, Vol. 75, No. 2, pp. 233-268.

Suggested Reading

Frank Jackson (1982), ‘Epiphenomenal Qualia’, Philosophical Quarterly, Vol. 32, pp. 127-36.

Ruth Garrett Millikan, ‘Biosemantics’, The Journal of Philosophy, Vol. 86, pp. 281-97.
